# Introduction

Trust in fellow citizens is the social glue that binds people together [@putnam_2000]. Putnam argues that declining social club enrollment---bowling alone, rather than with a club of people---is evidence of reduced social capital and trust held between citziens. Political parties have a particular interest in understanding social trust among their members [@lee_2022; @suh_2013]. Social trust influences what messages are resonant, and what information channels are effective in political outreach. When social trust is high, positive messages between co-partisans might be especially effective; when it is low, negative broadcast messaging may drive more people to the polls. This study compares levels of trust between Democratic and Republican voters in the United States in an attempt to evaluate current levels of social trust.

# Data

The American National Election Studies (ANES) conducts regular surveys of voters in the United States. This analysis uses data from the 2024 ANES Time Series study, which took place immediately before and after the 2024 presidential election. The ANES uses multistage stratified cluster sampling, with some surveys conducted in-person and some over the web. In both modes, the sampling frame was derived from the U.S. Postal Serviceâ€™s computerized delivery sequence file. Participants were offered financial awards of up to \$100 for completing the survey. This sampling process produces population representative estimates when analysis incorporates survey weights to adjust for different response rates across demographic characteristics. This analysis will not use the survey weights, potentially limiting generalizability to the US population.

## Measuring Democrats and Republicans

We use the variable `V241227x` (SUMMARY: PARTY ID) to operationalize whether a respondent is a Democrat and Republican. This variable measures party ID on a 7-point scale and is computed from responses on other questions. In line with political science literature, you decide to include people who "lean" towards a party as members [@petrocik_2009].
